author: dedlefou

description.text:
This is a nightlight based on the Fallout 3 Nuka Cola Lamp. The cola bottle is a remix of ShaAli, Coke Bottle http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26234. I made it larger, filled in the base, and added a few holes for wires and mounting. I designed it to run off a 5v USB cable, as well as added mounts for uses with devlab 2 AAA Battery Holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35515. I've added options for either three 3mm LEDs, or one 5mm. The design also leaves room for customization of the LED mounts. https://tinkercad.com/things/dMad5jc671c I used an oversized switch because I liked the look, and I had it on hand at the time. I added a diffuser, because I wanted it more as a nightlight then reading lamp. All parts fit snug together. I used 4 #4 screws on the base to hold the bottle in place. The label was created by Whatpayne http://whatpayne.deviantart.com/art/Nuka-Cola-old-school-batch-pt1-118806693 I reduced the size by 50%. This thing was made with Tinkercad.
Edit it online: #Fallout
https://tinkercad.com/things/7n0HN4Ts5SC
https://tinkercad.com/things/dMad5jc671c - Plugs

I've added many reference photos to help with the construction.  The lamp shade can be printed either as one color or two if you have a dual printer.  I printed the shade with 0% infill, 4 layers, and .30 height.  And it seems to work rather well. The LEDs will snap fit into the mount, but you might have to clean them a little.  I printed them several times in development, and sometimes I had to clean out the holes, and sometimes I did not.  The Lamp Plug has two parts.  The larger LED mount and the smaller plug.  If you don't plan on adding LEDs, skip the larger one.  The small plug connects the shade, and mount to the body.  I had no issue keeping the two connected without the mount.  Even dropped it once, and it stayed together.  I used rubber cement to glue the label on; this helped me with positioning, but did need to be cleaned up after.  
I'm thinking of modding this one to be a true nightlight, I'll just have to wait and see.

A couple of hubs that let you build quarter cubic honeycomb structures. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarter_cubic_honeycomb The quarter cubic honeycomb is a short step from the triakis truncated tetrahedron, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triakis_truncated_tetrahedron which is part of the crystal structure of diamonds. Hub holes are sized for 1/8" rod or dowels. Also can be used to make an abstract turkey for Thanksgiving.

description.text: Penta Twist Ashtray Low Poly. More Designs at http://www.ateliehacker.com

I needed an enclosure for a small prototype PCB I had made, like this:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/10Pcs-5-x-7-cm-DIY-Prototype-Paper-PCB-fr4-Universal-Board-prototyping-pcb-kit-/181846671646? In the description of the PCB, it is said to be 50x70 mm, but it actually is 51x71 mm, and that is what this box is designed for. The PCB slide in via a slot on each side of the inclosure, and sits quite snug. There is 4 mm space underneath the PCB, whis is plenty for pins and wiring, and 18 mm on top of the PCB, whis is enough for an arduino nano (or micro, nodemcu, etc) mounted in a pin header. I designed three different boxes and three different lids. The only differenec between the boxes is the amout of ventilation holes. The difference between the three lids is one does not have any holes, one a one slot/grove that allows for some cables, and the last one has a hole for a usb connector to an arduino (e.g.), if the arduino is mounte on the pin header.

author: veeresh

description.text:
This is an extruder upgrade designed specifically for the Replicator 2X similar to whpthomas, and others, but with improvements.
-base is fully printable without supports(REV3=DESIGN TWEAKS)
-arm is printable with only external supports (bearing slot)
-arm integrates feed tube mount as well(REV3=DESIGN TWEAKS)
-tension spring geometry improved (REV3=MORE TENSION)
-use 5/32" and 1/4" bits for tight clearance bearing/arm pivot holes
-uses Makerbot hardware kit for Rep2 + 1 extruder screw ($8 ea from Makerbot.com)
-can be pre-assembled for quick swap (under 2 minutes each)
-L and R extruder parts included, and labelled (common pin)

-Acquire the Rep2 extruder upgrade kit hardware only. ($8 ea shoudler bolt, small FH screw, bearing, spring) from Makerbot
-I printed it at 0.27mm layer with no support on base, and external supports for the arm just because of the bearing channel.
-you will need to chase the bore for the bearing shoulder bolt with a 5/32" drill bit just to make sure it is a tight fit.
-you may need to chase the 1/4" pivot hole in the arm to make sure it is a tight fit as well.
-you will need to lightly file the pin flats, and round edges to make it fit tight into the base key slot
-the base key slot has a relief at the bottom to make sure the pin seats flush and square with no radius in the corners Pre-Assembly: -included parts are LH-Arm, LH-Base, RH-Arm, RH-Base, and a common pin (print 2 of them, and one each of the others)
-put the small flathead screw into the deep corner countersunk hole in the base part.
-put the pin into the arm part so it is flush on the outside face
-put the bearing into the arm slot and secure with the shoulder bolt
-shoulder bolt head should be flush to the outside face, and the threads should stick out the back
-bearing should spin freely
-put arm onto base rotating the pin so the shoulder bolt threaded end rests in the curved slot in the base face.
  • now that the movement is limited in the arm via the threaded end in the slot you can add the spring
    -place the spring on the bottom perch and compress it into the arm perch.
    pre-assembly complete.
    • -follow makerbot instructions on how to remove the existing extruder.
    -place the newly pre-assembled extruder upgrade onto the stepper. You may have to compress the arm slightly to move the bearing out of the way of the drive gear.
    -new extruder should seat flush to the stepper face.
    -use one of the long flathead screws from the removed Makerbot extruder through the corner pin to secure the new 2X extruder upgrade to the stepper.
    -tighten until snug, but arm moves freely with very slight resistance.
    -press the arm down until you can insert the hex-key though the arm hole to tighten the small flathead screw in the other corner.
    -repeat entire procedure for the extruder upgrade for the other side. Please let know if you have any suggestions on improvements.

comments.text: Greetings,  could I trouble you for a set of arms to use with  624ZZ bearings please? ID 4mm,  OD 13mm, width 5mm . Thank you.
comments.author: tibuck

comments.text: Hi there...so you want a LH and RH arm to fit the specified bearing? The bearing has the same bore, but is 1mm wider, and 3mm larger in diameter.  This will mean a redesign of the geometry of the arm to ensure the same contact point, angle, and maybe force...we'll have to see how the arm lengths change.  The larger diameter bearing, and the repositioning of it, may also interfere with the cooling tube (if you are also using the cooling fan option for the Makerbot Replicator 2X we have...it works well.

comments.text: There's been a lot of problems printing PLA on the 2X. The current theory is the filament gets too soft when printing. Do you think it would be possible to take this extruder upgrade and modify it so that the drive gear is farther away from the barrier tube?
comments.author: furicks

comments.text: It would take a re-engineer of the way the stepper gets attached to the carriage.  Also with the increased distance you may need a guide tube to make sure the filament doesn't bend/kink as it is being fed into the tube.  The extruder as-is would be fine, it's just finding a way to increase the distance.  Basically, I think, you would need to mill a new aluminum base with the original tube attachment, but with higher mounting holes to relocate the stepper/extruder/fan assembly higher, and away from the heat source.  We would have to do a thermal study to really see what would happen, and how much distance would keep the PLA under the threshold temperature.
comments.author: furicks

comments.text: can you post the cad file?  I'd like to see the chamfer on the side closest to the pivot pin extended all the wat to the top of the square boss.  A 45 degree angle would allow for great printed without support if this chamfer were sitting flat on the build plate.  Thanks!
comments.author: 3FPD

comments.text: We just post the STL files so others can use and share our designs with others.  We do try to get all our designs to print without supports, as long as it does not interfere with operation, or ergonomics of the part. We are constantly trying to improve the designs with feedback from users.  We will take your design change suggestion into account when the next round of improvements are made.  Thanks.

Galvos laser scanners, based on nema 17 stepper motors. This laser scanner is designed to be used in a SLA 3d printer to replace the expensive Projector. Steppers are driven by pololu A4988 stepper driver, with a 1/16 micro stepping, moving a light weight mirror doesn't need that much torque from the stepper motors, this is why i believe the micro stepping is efficient here. The laser positioning is not accurate yet and needs more improvements. Very fast laser positioning will result in laser distortion, i guess this is due to the mirrors quality and the mechanical limitations of the stepper motors. But in lower speeds this would do the trick for SLA printers as the resin needs to exposed to the laser beam for enough time. Project is still in first phases and need more development, feel free to edit, improve and contribute back to this project. A video to show the galvos in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6L_4MTKywEk Project files can be found on github:
https://github.com/waleedq/salvos

title: Leapfrog creatr e3D bowden mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As the title says , this is a mount for the e3D hotend in bowden configuration. All in all this was a fun project to convert my printer from direct drive to bowden.
The original leapfrog fans still supply enough airflow for the cooling fins to remain cool to the touch. So i didn't add the e3D fan.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

30-40%

Notes:
  • I printed it in PLA to reduce warping.
  • Designed to be printed without supports.

in order to successfully convert to bowden you need to do a few things:
  • Relocate extruder steppers
  • Reverse the direction of the extruder steppers (can be done by reversing a coil or change it in the configuration.h file)
  • Change the thermistor setting in configuration.h to 5
  • PID tuning (very important) (M303)
  • Put the PID values in your marlin configuration.h file

comments.author: JAMh

description.text:
This is the pattern we use to dynamically level the build plate. (Rep 2X) It seems to work much better than the paper method It gives a true idea of how the extruder will deposit the print. Gallery pics show warped plate possible fix (note at end of instructions)
Pic 1: Print lifting on my warped plate
Pic 2: Print lifting on my warped plate
Pic 3: Straightedge showing plate warping
Pic 4: Difference in plate level once nuts loosened (had to lower Z-Axis limit switch almost 0.200")
Pic 5: Warp in plate gone once nuts adjusted.

-start by tightening the three leveling screws 1 full turn.
-start printing the pattern.
-as it is printing the circles, adjust the screws until you have a consistent pattern for the entire path of one circle.
-micro adjust until you have it at the optimal "squish" to make sure your parts adhere to the plate properly.
-cancel the print when you have a level plate.
-I have found this works better than the paper method as it reflects how the print will actually be extruded onto your HBP.
-I level my plate after every 4-5 prints.
-I also clean the Kapton tape with acetone between prints to promote better adhesion (even fingerprints will affect adhesion)
-I have found that 115° HBP works for ABS well. Note: Some 2X HBP's from the factory have their adjusting screws tightened so much that the induced stress is actually warping the plate, making leveling difficult if not impossible. If there is more than 1/16" of screw showing below the adjusting nut, and your plate is warping, they may be too tight. Loosening the adjuster nuts until the screw is flush to the bottom of the nut may relieve the stress and flatten the HBP(use a straightedge before and after to see if it helps). If it does flatten, this may also necessitate the adjusting of the Z-Axis limit switch location down as the plate will be much higher than factory settings. Just some thoughts that may help others with prints lifting at corners due to a warped HBP, etc.

title: Overlord Cherry MX Holder for manual calibration of bed

description.text:
This is a small device that may be useful when doing manual advanced leveling procedure
http://www.dreammaker.cc/forum/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=163 I did it because
  • I didn't like paper method
  • I wanted to keep hotend dissasembly to minimum
    • This one only requires you to unsrew stock layer fan and temporaly raise it higher It can be mounted to screw holes for second extruder (you might want to unsrew and raise layer fan temporaly) Attach a led with battery to switch and manually level the bed. After you've adjusted the height of all bed screws you'll only need to adjusts inital Z offset — this can be done after switch is no longer present http://screenshots.ryotsuke.ru/scr_d40542441eed.png http://screenshots.ryotsuke.ru/scr_749dcb80b9be.png For reference: cherry switch should touch buildplate at about Z7.0 and should turn on at Z6.5 or something

comments.text: Nice dryer knob, I was wondering did you print it with the shaft up like in the .stl image or did you have it down when you printed it?
comments.author: mb20music

comments.text: I printed it with the shaft up like in the .stl, to try and keep pressure off of it so it didn't warp the inside semi-circle while it was cooling. I also included some supports for the larger round piece, but didn't print enough on the one I did (shown in the photograph) as some of the first layer of bridging was drooping.

Simple Delta 3D Printer Enclosure This design uses common components from Home Depot or similar. Notches are cut out in the plastic and acrylic sheet to secure the sheeting in place. A roll of 2" nylon tape can be used to seal up the enclosure. A Dremel was used to cut notches in the acrylic sheet. Each sheet flexes into place and is held together by notches and tape. title: K8200 Z-Axis cable driven stabilizer / parallel drive

description.text:
The original part wasn't strong enough for my application, so i made a version that is strong
enough for my needs. Also provided are some picures of my printer that show my setup. On the pictures
you can see that the tentioner i use, doesn't collide with the pulleys, and has enough space
to get me my Zmax of 218mm and has room to spare.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.6mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:
  • 0.8mm nozzle
  • 0.6mm layer hight
  • 100% infill.

Please take a look at the Original post for more advanced instructions and
the rest of the parts you need to print.

Now all that could be improved are the pulleys, the big one seems strong enough for
the tention, but one of the small ones has split on me though.
I think it would be best to buy metal ones, or maby find a way to fix the printed ones.
Because the layers are parallel with the rope, it's doomed to split under high tention.
Also the way of mounting the pulleys could me improved. Having one screw to hold the bearing, and one or two others to fasten the part. This way the bearing could move more freely. Drilling all the way trough the aluminium profile to mount two pulleys with one screw
would also be a really good way, i think.

comments.text: Actually, the diameter of the small pulleys is not critical to their operation, so it would be reasonable to make bigger ones, perhaps with a groove that is better able to conform to the cable. I agree that the mounting system should be redesigned, and the small raised step that the bearings sit on should be smaller diameter or replaced on both sides of the bearing with M8 washers, to make sure it won't grip the outer rotating part if overtightened. I am considering a scheme to have the bottom pulleys sliding down for tensioning the wires, perhaps pushing them down with a bolt. I really should redesign this in OpenSCAD
comments.author: Brandano

comments.text: I don't use the printed parts that go around the bearings anymore, they broke a long time ago. I already made the change to washers. That might work but i think it's better to design it defrent. With the little room you have to tention, and the printbed being 1mm away from it. I don't think there is alot of room to work with. The tentioners i use can tention more then needed. As everything i did to your design was overkill it. I might look into overkilling the pulleys next as i don't use this system atm. I have trouble with it making too much friction and giving me Z... what's the word.. The Z axis doesn't have a spring pushing down on it so it stays up and screws up the first few layers. I'm thinking about designing a mechanism with an RC spring to push down on it.

author: Karlsen3D

description.text: A complete set of the Catalan solids. Catalan solids are the duals of the Archimedan solids. They're face-transitive, which means that (like the Platonic solids) they can be used to make inherently fair dice. They have the additional constraint that all of the dihedral angles (angles between adjacent faces) are the same.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: The rhombic dodecahedron prints fine without supports, but all of the rest of them will probably need them. All are oriented according to the closest they have to cubic symmetry, which means that all but the rhombic tricontahedron will need to be rotated to put a face horizontal. Needed resolution will vary from solid to solid.

All of these solids were created in TinkerCad (collection here). I wasn't satisfied with the one-degree precision TinkerCad allows in rotations, so I created a shape generator which allows arbitrary rotation of a box given the three Euler angles, to a precision of 0.01 degree. In turn, I used this box to define all of the faces of the solids. Some of the more complicated solids required rotations of shapes already on the workspace; to do this, I superimposed one of my precision-rotated boxes, and then used workplanes and copy-paste to unrotate the superimposed box.

title: Klein Bottle for Home (by Bithome)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: The Klein Bottle materializes the imagination of the greatest mathematicians anywhere you place it. This 4-Dimensional object only has one side, the inside being the same as the outside. It cannot be made in real life. In fact, not even current 3D modeling programs can handle the unreal features of the bottle. The Klein bottle is the perfect example of a design that can only be made in the future. This tall bottle is ideal to exhibit in large environments such as your living room. Like all my designs, It was created by mixing engineering and art. Its mathematical pattern looks modern and showcases the Klein Bottle's impossible geometry, all while being lightweight and providing excellent structural strength. If you want to learn how I pulled this design off, you can read its story at http://thebithome.tumblr.com/ You can also purchase a high res SLS printed Klein Bottle through the Bithome store at http://shpws.me/KBGl

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300

Infill:

100

Notes: Ideally this design requires an SLS printer. However, it is not impossible to print it with an FDM printer. title: V3 - e3d clone fan ducts 360° - print and barrel ! - high performance

description.text:
WARNING: IMPROVED VERSION HERE!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1292065

this is the 3rd iteration (but 5th internal :) of my fan ducts for the e3d hotend.
it cools both the print AND the barrel.
what's new:
the flow is now 360° around the print, and it flows A LOT of air.
the backpressure from the fans is really low, it flows more than twice the previous iteration.
this is due to the conic volume filler and the carefully optimized geometry. the flow is not perfectly simmetrical because it takes in consideration the real flow from a real fan (a sanyo denki 40x40x20) which has a rotational component.
(and for who wonders, this is a good thing because turbulence cools the print better)

description.text: Demon Frintessa Fantasy figure + texture pack

This carriage increases X travel to 285mm, from 270mm. Y travel increased to 245mm from 230mm. It allows mounting of 2x 40mm fans on either side of the hot end for superior active cooling. Belt just slides in from underneath and is held in snug. No clamping necessary! Linear bearing clamps hold pretty tight without screws for me, but the holes are there if you need em. I'm using Rob65's awesome spring loaded extruder here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62468 I used a J-head hot end, and have not tested it with the stock. But I dont see why it wouldn't work fine. 2 STL's to choose from. One with a cable chain support, and one without. Print on its side, with supports enabled on the large gaps. All screw holes print fine without supports.

comments.text: In this carriage the extrusion motor is assembled upside down when compared to the original setup. I now face the problem that when I use the retraction command in S3D it extrudes instead. How did you change the direction of the motor in this setup?
comments.author: 3Dash

comments.text: Mounting a motor upside down does not change its direction.  Each of the original extruders spin in opposite directions from eachother as one feeds from the left side of the motor shaft, and other on the right.  This single extruder is set up like the right side on the original carriage.  You likely just used the wiring for the left extruder.  Just switch to the wiring for the right, and it will extrude correctly.  Another solution is to modify the firmware's config.h, or physically swap the wiring polarity on the motor.
comments.author: 3Dash

comments.text: Thank you for the reply. I realise that my explanation about the motor being upside down wasn't the best. I fixed the problem by mirroring the square hole for the nozzle to the other side. I remixed your wonderful model so you can check it out if you want.

comments.text: I made this the other day -- it works nicely, but the part falls off the top of the i3PRO pretty regularly.  Does this happen to you as well?  It seems like the aperture for grabbing onto the steel frame is wider than the frame by enough margin to let it wiggle loose over time.
comments.author: petergrace

comments.text: No that doesn't happen with mine. But it could also be the thickness of the powder coat on your frame. Double check the thickness with a pair of calipers. You might have to experiment by scaling down to 0.95 or 0.90 uniform scale. The gap in the guide is exactly 3mm to fit on the frame. Like I said, you can experiment or you can give me a couple of days and I can do a redesign the incorporates a thumb screw at the back for adjustments. Your choice. Hope that helps.

comments.text: A thumb screw!  That would work perfectly!  I'll tap a hole and put one in, but that's not a bad idea for a revision to the design.

author: parachutefactory

description.text:
Here is a brood to the bird family. Related to the wingspan, it is a crossbreed of the
"Red Duck" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:407766
and the
"Red Swan" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:453090
Still small, but speedy and pretty manoeuvrable - a big fun for a real pilot.
Anyhow, Marcel, member of the ACNE http://www.aero-club-nieder-eschbach.de/
who piloted the maiden flight, had a lot of fun and this is his first impression:
"The small model is already very good, but some model flying experience is needed. For a wing type of this small size it flies even damned good. It’s not a plane for circling through thermics, of course it’s to small for that. The performance is shown when one flies it speedingly". Uwe Heuer - experienced flying wing designer and Horton specialist - says about this square form of a flying wing, which he loves to call "panel plane": "They do have a low damping and flight stability around the pitch axis (elevator), therefore you can fly snags in curves. This is why I love these “panel-planes”, these are also good-tempered against tilting to one side. But on the other side you pay that with the high sensitivity regarding wrong trimming of the CG and the elevator. During stall the wings stay level but for recovery they need a long dive to speed up again". Besides my other planes it was flying at the InterEx 2016 in Versiox/Geneva
http://jivaro-models.org/interex_2016/index.html
They were very enthusiastic about of the speed which is possible.
But we dicovered that it is also posssible to land it slowly. Here you can see how it flies:
https://youtu.be/d8cFB1equik
https://youtu.be/QrYqn8kItYM This small plane is quickly printed.The biggest parts are 220mm high to print, but I also sliced them in half. Wing fixating
Additional to fasten the wing with rubber band, it is important to secure it against sliding sidewards. You can do this by simply fixiating it with a short tape at front and at back to the fuselage. Update 11.23.2015
Uploaded smaller wing segments:
wing middle left 110
wing middle right 110
wind left right 110
And smaller front fuselage segments:
fuselage front 1
fuselage front 2
fuselage interface front Update 12.14.2015
Uploaded smaller back fuselage segments:
fuselage back 1
fuselage fback 2
fuselage interface back Update 01.04.2016

Attention
The wings are designed to print with 0.5 width, 0.3 hight and 2 bottom and top layer
If you print thinner, the perimeter of the upper side will not merge with the perimeter of the inner spars.
If you print thicker, the perimeter will not be printed continuesly in one turn.
The print must go as if you print in spiral vase mode. So you reach at least a smooth surface on the upper side.
If needed, you must try with 0.49 or 0.48 width. It depends on which slicer you use.
The second thing is, if you print with less layer hight, the inner spars will not connect the top and the bottom layer. There will be a gap inbetween. All parts: layer height =0,3mm, width =0.5 mm

comments.text:
Cura and Slic3r have each their benefits but I can't see they would differ in print quality. All depends on the settings.
But no matter which slicer I use, I always check the gcode in the preview of the Repetier Host.
There you can check very detailed every move of the print.
Go to "Edit G-Code"
Select "Show Single Layer"
Go to the layer you want to check and select "Last Layer"
It brings you to the last line of this layer.
Now you can go step by step backwards by using the up arrow key. Every move will light up now.
To see it better select a light color for "Selected Filament" (Confic - Preferences - Filament)
Note: you can only see the movements on the selected layer.
Repetier Host has Cura and Slic3r integrated: https://www.repetier.com/

I use two 4mm carbon tubes, 800mm long.

Besides my other planes it was flying at the InterEx 2016 in Versiox/Geneva

Man kann PLA sehr gut mit einem Kleber aus dem Baumarkt kleben und zwar:
Marley Spezialkleber für Dachrinnensysteme.
Die Tube enthält 100 Gramm des Klebers ist also so groß wie eine Zahnpaststube und der Kleber hält bombenfest.
Anwendung , Kleber auftragen , ca 2 Minuten festhalten Reste sofort entfernen und schon hält das Ding.

comments.author: schnabelschnut

comments.text:
Danke, ich freue mich, dass er Dir gefällt.
Ich bevorzuge Epoxykleber z.B. Uhu Endfest 300. Er löst aber nicht an, dafür bekommt man gebrochene Teile jedoch notfalls wieder abgeschält.
Stumpf aufeinander geklebte Teile haften sehr schlecht. Bei genügend Überlappungsfläche, wie z.B. die verschraubten Zargen beim Rumpf, oder (falls der Rumpf vorn und hinten geteilt werden muss) die Verbindungslaschen innen, entsteht ausreichende Haftung. Da wirkt Epoxy als Füller zwischen den Druckriefen.
Die beiden Nachbauten von meinem Motorsegler wurden nur mit Sekundenkleber verklebt. Der hält besser, man muss sich jedoch etwas beeilen.
http://www.thingiverse.com/make:158813
Richtig anlösen tut nur Dichormethan. Das ist aber mit großer Vorsicht anzuwenden und verflüchtigt sich so schnell, dass man es nicht auftragen kann. Man kann es nur aus einer dünnen Kanüle vorsichtig in einen Spalt fließen lassen und hoffen, dass es sich durch die Kappilarwirkung weit genug verteilt.

comments.author: JohnLox

comments.text:
Hi John,
You need the interface only if you can't print the large parts of the fuselage (front 202, back 190)
The fuselage parts front 1 and front 2 needs the interface to connect both parts.
The interfaces are supposed to put them fifty-fifty in each fuselage part. In this way the parts are aligned and easy to glue.
Before gluing you should mask the edges of the fuselage with tape to keep them clean from glue.
After that, you must cut out the front interface in the range of the opening.
The same has to be done on the back fuselage but I didn't sliced it yet.
Wing
If you can't print the large wing parts, the order is as following (from middle to the right side):
wing middle right 110
wing servo right
wing left right 110
wing left right 110
wing end right

UPDATE NOTICE: 1/20/2016
The 2016 BUTToN GEAR is now available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1282654 For all of you that have ever needed an extra little incentive to get your Butt in Gear I present the official 2015 BUTToN GEAR! Yes, this is intended to be puny. It comes in two styles this year... so far: The Functional button that can actually be used on your clothing, and the Token button to simply carry around with you. Stay tuned for more. These are big buttons meant to be seen. Display it on your coat, sweater, shirt, pocket, sleeve, backpack, purse, briefcase, or whatever strikes your fancy. Update 11/7/15: Here is more http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1117719 An alternate attachment style using two slots instead of four holes. This will allow for easy attachment to additional items like shoe laces, thin straps, hair clips or ribbons. As this is part of an on going campaign stay tuned for the 2016 versions to come out around the beginning of the year at which time the current files posted here will disappear. Changes may be subtle or dramatic but something will change every year. NOTICE UPDATE 1/12/2016: I have reconsidered and will leave these old files here after all. Turns out that if I remove them they will disappear from your collections. For those of you that print this object I invite you to post images of the various methods you come up with to tastefully display it. The STL files are CURA scaled and ready to print in a 35 mm size. I show in the pictures both the 35 mm and a scaled up 40 mm print of both styles. Use a scale ratio of 1.141 to get the 40 mm size. The smallest size I have printed and still had readable (barely) is 30 mm.
Here is the challenge: How small can you print this and still have it look good?
Alternate challenge: What's the biggest usable button you can print? So, what are you waiting for? Get your BUTToN GEAR!

Bottom and top layers 0.6 - 0.8 mm thick.

Where the idea came from. A friend mentioned that he needed to get his butt in gear and get home on his bike before it started to rain again. I asked "What does a button gear look like?" He paused and then said "That's actually a funny idea." The next day I placed an early concept of the token version on his desk. Now it has been released to the Thingiverse world. I designed this in trueSpace 6.6.

title: BT Youview Box Aerial Socket protector

description.text:
The aerial socket on my BT Youview box continually lost connection with the cable plug centre conductor. I traced the problem to the heavy, low loss aerial cable that was stiff and so whenever the box was moved it was opening the central split connector on the box. 
This sleeve fits over the aerial socket and plug and stops that movement.
It is designed to have O-rings inserted in the grooves to keep tension on the socket and plug.
Printed in PLA with 0.2mm layers and no support material.

comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: Thanks for responding. :-)  I can see how this setup does a nice job of illuminating the project as it prints but it still looks to me that the darkest place at the "building site" would be the very point where the plastic emerges from the tip.  I know I'm just being OCD about this.  Its your printer and the ring is serving you well and that's wonderful.  In my case I have 3 SMD LED from an RGB light strip mounted down near the head.  That way I can clearly witness the extrusion process and make z-axis adjustments while the print job is just getting started.  For me it helps to be able to see whether the plastic is being laid out on the surface lazily (bad) or being forced out through a tiny gap between the platform and the print head. (good)  You may not have such issues with your delta unit.  ( I hope. :-) )  The reason why other lighting ideas like yours interest me is that it probably would be low glare for the webcam.  I get wicked glare from the SMDs bouncing off the shiny Aluminum that I print on. :-)  (I gladly will put up the glare.  In the past I broke many sheets of glass.  I have yet to brake one of my 1/4 inch thick pieces of Aluminum. :-) )

title: Coyote OYO alternative mount for Renault Captur

description.text:
The mounting system that comes with the Coyote OYO driving assistant only allows dashboard mounting. This means that leaving the device on the dashboard in in some public places is an invitation to bad experiences. So I devised a holder that allows to place the Oyo in a more discrete location: under the central console, while still remaining clearly visible for the driver.
A pair of 30x10x3mm magnets in the base device and the holder provide strong retention,  allow to quickly remove the Oyo and the holder by just pulling on them and also provides some security if the Oyo is accidentally pushed aside by a passenger. The base could be fixed under the central console with a pad of adhesive foam.
A series of slots in the vertical portion of the holder allows flexion to ease the insertion of the Oyo.
Sketchup files are provided should you want to modify the holder or the base to change the angles...

author: Laurycamargob

description.text:
Creates an insert pipe bend that sits flush with a pipe of the specified size, yielding a smooth outer surface when assembled. Usage:
insert_pipe_bend(bend_angle, bend_radius, insert_length, pipe_outer_diameter, pipe_inner_diameter <, hollow_diameter>); The resulting bend has an angle of bend_angle, with a radius measured along the centerline of bend_radius. At each end is an insert section of length insert_length to slide into the connecting pipes. The connecting pipe dimensions are specified by the parameters pipe_outer_diameter and pipe_inner_diameter. The optional parameter hollow_diameter creates a passageway through the center of the bend with the specified diameter; omitting it creates a completely solid bend.

title: Land Pride (Kubota) Finish Mower Wheel Spacer and Sleeve
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I lost a couple height-setting spacers one day when the nut that holds them came loose and the bolt dropped out. Rather than pay for new ones, I slapped this together. They hold up for around 1 season of mowing (7 or 8 months) before they break down enough to require replacing. Adding a fender washer to the top (and even bottom) would drastically improve their lifespan. See time-lapses of the things I print here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQ9nW8XQAPWKGGKRd9LFQNQ

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Irrelevant

Infill:

50%

Notes: The spacer is a simple cylinder and the sleeve isn't complex either, so supports aren't needed and resolution is irrelevant. These are work pieces, not show pieces. I opted for 50% infill to ensure the piece was strong enough to hold up over several months of jostling while mowing a few acres each week.

It was a fairly basic exercise of grabbing the calipers to measure an existing spacer and sleeve, then translating that to a design in 123D Design.  I rounded some of the edges to ease fitting and reduce stress points, but that's probably overkill in this application.  The 123D Design files are included to make modification easier should you need to.

Wide angle lens mount for DLink DCS 932L (and quite possible other dling webcams). I wanted to get a wider angle cam for monitoring my printer. I found an article of a guy who had bought a cheap wide angle lens kit for smartphones, and he had just glued one of the lenses to his web cam. I tought I needed a printed solution for that :) I bought a really cheap lens kit on ebay. The image i far from perfect, but still much better then the "telelens" that comes on the dcs 932l. http://www.ebay.com/itm/131505512122?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT Update: I just added a version 2 of the lens holder. The reason for version 2 is, that the widest of the lenses have a small collar that snaps perfect onto version 1. The other lens (the 0.67x) does not have this collar, and will therefore have to be mounted via the very fine threads. I have to say that I like the original version better, and if you are only going to use the wides angle lens in the kit in the link, I would still recommend that you use the original design (un-versioned). Update 160119: Added version 3. This version has a 14mm hole for the lens mount and 1.8mm material thickness around the lens.

comments.text: This is a fantastic idea! But, it doesn't fit the lenses I have. Any chance of a version of the original where the opening diameter is 14mm and the plastic around the opening is only 1.8mm thick?  I've got the "Neewer" set from Amazon.

comments.author: joestraws

comments.text:
It is about tolerances... when scaling a drawing from auto cad it will export it as a 1:1 unit scale. So when scaling up a part that was drawn in Inches you will have to scale the part up 25.4x to create a 1 to 1 scale model as it was drawn. Knowing your printer as i do mine requires a .02(inch) (.18x - .16x = .02x difference) tolerance to allow a shaft to fit in a hole or in this case a screw to fit in a hole with the threads drawn with machined screw tolerances. Your printer may have different tolerances when it comes to its ability to be able to print machined screw thread tolerances.. as would everyones else.
Scaling a screw in only the z-axis will change the threads and cause them to not align properly.
The handle was sanded down to create a nice sliding fit.
The main screw prints out great vertically on my printer and it interacts with very little friction. This is not designed for actual use.

Presenting GroupHex, a modular organizer that can be arranged in myriad shapes in 3 dimensions. GroupHex is an evolution of the ubiquitous Honey comb pattern or the Hexagon shaped organizer. Taking a step forward from a fixed layout (like: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1092812) I designed GroupHex with 3 goals in mind: It should be relatively quick to print, Should be expandable and fun. GroupHex comes in four sizes: Short, Medium, Tall and Grande. There are 3 grooves and 3 ribs on the 6 sides of the Hexagon. These allow GroupHex units to be linked together at different relative heights, allowing the user to make their own unique Organizer, different from anyone else. There is another groove at the bottom of each unit allowing even more flexibility in linking the units in Horizontal and Vertical Orientation.

This is a 3D scale replica of the United States, the state height corresponds to the number of electoral votes each state controls in a presidential election. I thought it could be a fun visual tool for learning about U.S. politics. Also included in this thing is a flat 2D Sketchup map of the U.S. suitable for resizing, extruding, scaling, puzzle making, you name it! More about this project in my blog post here: http://www.thenewhobbyist.com/2011/09/3d-printing-for-the-classroom/

• Print all 11 print beds
  • Assemble
  • Display and educate!

title: X-axis carriage for linear stepping motor.

description.text:
I designed the x-axis carriage.
The carriage use the one of brass nut which is included within the linear stepping motor when I buy it.
There is a backlash, but not big.
I wonder how the backlash would affect the print results.

comments.text:
, Hi
I like your design. Is it possible to do some mods?
I am busy building a CoreXY design machine but I want to use 8mm linear lead screws on both X and Y axis. This would work perfect if it had an add on for 8mm linear lead screw nut.
comments.author: jv71

comments.text: What hot end are you mounting on the X Carriage and how where you planning to do so as it is incredibly small and the bearing paths are extremely close to the hot end will no clearance for a fan or anything. You wouldn't happen to have the design file for the carriage would you as my lead screw nut is larger than what you modeled for and i'd like to not have to re-design the whole carriage.
comments.author: Timelord83

comments.text: Nice work. Wouldn't be hard to add an anti backlash nut with a spring and you are good to go. Well done!

comments.text:
Hey There,
I love this design idea. I would definitely use it. One Thing I would suggest.
To get rid of backlash, use two nuts for the x-carriage with a heavy duty spring between the nuts. This will put pressure on the nuts and reduce backlash to nothing. Hope that helps, maybe I will try and do some modifications when I get time

comments.text: Thanks for good comment! I well know the method to eliminate the backlash. But the linear stepping motor is too weak to handle the pre-pressurised two nuts. If I use the more powerful motor, It would be possible.

low poly horse standing ..
ROMAN STATUE

My Thetford cassette broke and I tracked it down to this part which had broken. I had several attempts at getting a good replacement part made up. I printed with 3 shells, 20% infill (but it should not need it), roof and floor thickness is 1mm. The 4 x 10mm towers around the part are to slow down the print so that the important center piece is printed without too much warp. It might not be as important for PLA print but I use ABS.
UPDATED: I found that alcohol influenced usage equaled breakage. The weak point being the tower to the big disc point. So I made some modifications to the design ... v6. I also recommend 100% infill if you can manage it without warping:) and go as slow as possible I dropped it down to 0.35x on sailfish. New design certainly feels stronger. Lets see how long this one lasts. I'm printing a spare and will pop a picture up soon.
